message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Butorphanol is a mixed agonist-antagonist opioid and can precipitate withdrawal symptoms in patients dependent on other opioids, such as opium. The patient's symptoms indicate opioid withdrawal. Hydrocodone, Fentanyl, and Oxycodone are full agonist opioids, and may also cause withdrawal symptoms in opium dependent patients, but are less likely to do so than Butorphanol.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only Butorphanol is known to cause withdrawal symptoms when used in patients with opioid dependency. The symptoms described by the patient suggest opioid withdrawal.

Butorphanol is a mixed opioid agonist-antagonist used to treat pain and is less likely to cause respiratory depression compared to other opioid drugs. However, it can cause withdrawal symptoms in patients who are physically dependent on opioids, such as the patient who had been smoking opium. This can manifest as chills, diaphoresis, nausea, and abdominal pain.
